nouns.definition: a roadside service area with facilities for refueling and resting, often with a restaurant or café for truckers and other motorists.
examples: We pulled over at the next truck stop to refuel and grab a bite to eat.
The truck stop was crowded with big rigs and travelers stopping for a rest.

nouns.definition: a list of dishes available in a restaurant.
examples: Oliver grabbed a menu from another table to check the beverages.
The restaurant had a varied menu, offering both local and international cuisine.

nouns.definition: a piece of material suspended at the top to form a screen, typically movable sideways along a rail and found as one of a pair at a window.
examples: He appeared from behind the plastic curtain with a look of confusion.
She drew the curtains together as the sun began to set.

nouns.definition: a dish not on the regular menu but offered on a particular day.
examples: We decided to try the daily special, hoping it would be something fresh.
The restaurant's special was always a surprise, featuring seasonal ingredients.

verbs.definition: operating and controlling the direction and speed of a motor vehicle.
examples: Oliver was driving while I was trying to find a place to stop and drink.
She was driving through the countryside, enjoying the scenic views.

verbs.definition: scattered about in an untidy manner; covered with or as if with scattered pieces of trash or litter.
examples: The tables were littered with crumbs and bottles after the lunch rush.
The park was littered with wrappers and cans after the concert.

verbs.definition: require (something) because it is essential or very important rather than just desirable.
examples: I desperately needed to drink something to quench my thirst.
He needed to finish the report by the end of the day.

verbs.definition: requested some product or service to be made, supplied, or served.
examples: Oliver ordered the drinks despite the waiter's silence.
She ordered a new book online and awaited its delivery.

phrasal_verbs.definition: to go on foot to a nearby location.
examples: He walked over to us with a confused expression.
After spotting her friend, she walked over to say hello.

phrasal_verbs.definition: to greet someone with the word 'hello'.
examples: We said hello to the waiter but received no reply.
I saw my neighbor on the street and said hello.

phrasal_verbs.definition: to tell a funny story or create a humorous situation.
examples: Oliver made a joke about the heat, trying to lighten the mood.
During the meeting, she made a joke that broke the ice with the new team members.

phrasal_verbs.definition: to leave or depart from a place by walking.
examples: After taking our order, the waiter walked away without another word.
She walked away from the conversation feeling frustrated.

idioms.definition: to not change or affect something at all.
examples: The whirring fan didn't move a hair on our heads, it was so weak.
His impassioned speech did not move a hair on the board members' convictions.

idioms.definition: to do something to help someone.
examples: I asked for the daily special to do the waiter a favor by keeping the order simple.
Could you do me a favor and pass the salt?

idioms.definition: to sit down or place oneself or something down heavily and carelessly.
examples: He looked as if someone had just plopped him down in the middle of the restaurant.
She plopped down on the couch after a long day at work.

idioms.definition: a phrase indicating that there is no further information to add or no need for further discussion.
examples: He walked away as though there was nothing more to say about the menu options.
After the argument, they parted ways with nothing more to say to each other.

title: Things We Lost in the Fire
author: Mariana Enríquez

nouns.definition: a female member of a royal family other than a queen, especially a daughter or granddaughter of a king or queen.
examples: She was treated like a suburban princess with the best toys and parties.
In fairy tales, a princess often needs to be rescued by a brave knight.

nouns.definition: a type of building or house, typically found in mountain regions, with overhanging eaves.
examples: Her enormous English chalet stood out in our gray neighborhood.
They rented a chalet for their ski holiday in the Alps.

nouns.definition: an artificial device that replaces a missing body part, which may be lost through trauma, disease, or a condition present at birth.
examples: She didn’t even want to use a prosthetic arm.
He learned to walk again with the help of a prosthetic leg.

nouns.definition: a mark left on the skin or within body tissue where a wound, burn, or sore has not healed completely and fibrous connective tissue has developed.
examples: She claimed the scar from the dog attack healed really well.
His scar from the appendectomy was still visible near his groin.

verbs.definition: to go to see and spend time with someone socially.
examples: Her memory doesn’t visit me during the day.
He plans to visit his grandmother this weekend.

verbs.definition: to differ in size, degree, or nature from something else of the same general class.
examples: My dreams of Adela vary, but there is always the rain.
The tasks vary each day in complexity.

verbs.definition: to look at or observe attentively over a period of time.
examples: We stood in front of the empty house and watched the police in the yard.
She likes to watch movies on the big screen.

verbs.definition: to move one's hand or a cloth repeatedly back and forth over the surface of something with firm pressure.
examples: If she saw repulsion, she was capable of rubbing her stump in their face.
He rubbed his hands together to generate warmth.

idioms.definition: to be treated with excessive indulgence and to behave poorly as a result.
examples: She was a suburban princess, spoiled rotten in that enormous English chalet.
The only child was spoiled rotten by his doting parents.

idioms.definition: having a shiny, grayish coating resembling silver.
examples: The water under the siesta sun looked silvered.
His hair was silvered with age.

idioms.definition: to feel disgust or strong aversion.
examples: A lot of the other kids were grossed out by her.
He was grossed out by the sight of raw meat.
Luckily she wasn’t left-handed.
Luckily, they arrived at the station just in time to catch the train.

nouns.definition: a person who designs buildings and in many cases also supervises their construction.
examples: The architect drew plans for a modern house.
They hired an architect to renovate their home.

nouns.definition: a single sheet of glass in a window or door.
examples: The baseball smashed through the window pane.
She cleaned the panes of the greenhouse.

nouns.definition: a hill or stretch of rolling grassland, especially in the British Isles.
examples: They picnicked on the down overlooking the village.
Sheep were grazing on the green downs.

nouns.definition: a place where tickets are sold for an event, or the financial success of a film or show.
examples: The movie was a hit at the box-office.
We need to collect our tickets at the box-office before the show starts.
Whenever I denigrate the place, Hugh reminds me of the view.
He shouldn't denigrate his opponent's achievements.

verbs.definition: to cause someone to remember someone or something.
examples: Hugh reminds me that it’s the view that counts.
She reminded him to take his medication.

verbs.definition: to feed on growing grass; to touch lightly in passing.
examples: The cows graze in the fields from dawn till dusk.
His hand grazed her shoulder as he walked by.

verbs.definition: to carry out an action or pattern of behavior; to entertain an audience by playing a role.
examples: I performed at the theatre last night.
The musician performed her new song live.

idioms.definition: not very attractive or impressive to view.
examples: The old car runs well, but it's nothing much to look at.
Their office building is nothing much to look at, but it's functional.

idioms.definition: the perspective or outlook that is considered important or valuable.
examples: When choosing a hotel room, it's the view that counts.
He may not be the most charismatic speaker, but it's his message that's the view that counts.

idioms.definition: to extend over a large area; to distribute or be distributed over a wide space.
examples: The beach towels were spread out on the sand.
The city is spread out across the valley.

nouns.definition: an insulated cabinet or chest with a partition for ice, used for preserving or cooling food and drinks; an old-fashioned term for a refrigerator.
examples: She went to the icebox to get some fresh fruit.
My grandmother still refers to her refrigerator as the icebox.

nouns.definition: pieces of fabric or other material intended to block or obscure light, or to provide privacy by covering a window or other opening.
examples: Jill was browsing through a catalogue in search of new curtains.
They drew the curtains as the sun began to set.

nouns.definition: a person who cleans and trims the fur of dogs and other animals as an occupation.
examples: Jill is a professional groomer who takes pride in her work.
The groomer at the pet salon gave the poodle a stylish haircut.

nouns.definition: a thin membrane that separates the outer ear from the middle ear and vibrates in response to sound waves; the tympanic membrane.
examples: Jill's second husband left her with a broken eardrum.
The loud explosion at the concert caused damage to his eardrum.

verbs.definition: to fill (a suitcase or bag), especially with clothes and other items needed for travel.
examples: My mother had already packed most of her dishes and kitchen things.
He packed his bag quickly, eager to begin his journey.

verbs.definition: to remove frost or ice from (a refrigerator or freezer); to thaw out (food or other items).
examples: She's waiting for the chicken to finish defrosting before she can cook it.
I need to defrost the freezer; it's completely iced over.

verbs.definition: to cook food in hot oil or fat.
examples: She needs to fry up the chicken before it spoils.
On weekends, we often fry up some bacon and eggs for breakfast.

verbs.definition: to recover from a setback or hardship.
examples: Despite the challenges, Jill has bounced back and found a job she enjoys.
The team bounced back from their defeat with a strong performance in their next game.

idioms.definition: a situation suddenly becomes noisy and violent, usually with a lot of people arguing or fighting.
examples: When Jill's children were kidnapped, all hell broke loose.
All hell broke loose in the courtroom after the verdict was announced.

idioms.definition: an expression of disbelief or amazement, often rhetorical, questioning whether something that has happened can be topped or believed.
examples: She was presented with a bill for the bridge repair, can you beat it?
He won the lottery twice in one year, can you beat it?
